msgSnippet: ... I think it depends on the context. If I am running tests on the desktop I usually want to stop on the first failure, fix it and move on to the next one. If
messageBody:
> Mike Clark wrote:
>
> >
> > On Nov 21, 2003, at 4:27 PM, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> > >
> > > ...and you don't mind that one failing test brings down
> the whole
> > > suite?
> >
> > Why should I mind as long as the failing test is fixed
> immediately?
> > As it is, one failing test brings down my whole build
> process anyway.
> > I consider that a good thing.
> >
> > I'm not trying to be facetious. I'm really trying to learn
> something
> > new in all of this.

I think it depends on the context. If I am running tests on the desktop
I usually want to stop on the first failure, fix it and move on to the
next one.

If we are running a large set of automated tests for a build of an
entire system that has code that spans multiple developers, it may be
preferable to complete the entire test with a report of multiple errors
that the developers can scurry off with and recreate on their own, one
error at a time. On the other hand it some times works out better to run
the build tests and stop on the first error, with developers taking
turns in the 'hot seat' to fix their problem and start the build tests
again.

It really depends on which approach is most efficient for the team,
given the application under test and the length of time it takes to run
the complete set of tests.
